ArticleInfo.ArticleTitle: Characteristics of nano-plasmonic resonators with a gap structure

Affiliation.OrgDivision: Department of Systems and Control Engineering
Department of Advanced Materials Science, Faculty of Engineering
Department of Optical Science and Technology, Faculty of Engineering

Abstract.Heading: Abstract
Abstract.Para: The authors present a nano-plasmonic disk resonator with a gap structure using the multi-mode interference effect coupling. The coupling intensity of the multi-mode interference effect coupling is 1.5 times greater than that of the conventional side coupling. The multi-mode interference effect is adopted as the coupling between the input bus waveguide and the nano-plasmonic disk resonator. The thickness of the dielectric layer, the width of the bus waveguide, and the length of the coupling portion are designed by theoretical calculations.

Section1.Heading: Introduction
Section1.Para: To realize nano-scale photonic integrated circuits, plasmonic devices with the order of visible and telecom wavelengths of light are investigated. Many plasmonic resonators have been reported [1–5] because nano-resonators play an important role as the building component of nano-scale photonic integrated circuits. The ring, rectangle, racetrack, and disk resonators can be used for add/drop filters, band-pass filters, wavelength multiplexers/demultiplexers, and optical switches [1–5]. The disk geometry has advantages in terms of smaller radiation losses as compared with the ring geometry [4]. However, the size of these structures is more than 5 μm. The size of plasmonic resonators that are used for nano-scale photonic integrated circuits should decrease. The coupling portion between the bus waveguide and the resonator reduces when the size of the resonator structure such as a ring and disk resonator decreases. This causes the decrease of the coupling efficiency between the bus waveguide and the resonator. Therefore, the decrease of the size and the increase of the coupling efficiency are required for a nano-plasmonic resonator used in nano-scale photonic integrated circuits.

Multi-mode interference (MMI) is in that modes such as the fundamental mode interfere with higher order modes in the multi-mode waveguide. The MMI produces a self-imaging that field profiles reproduced in periodic images [6, 7]. Conventional optical applications that adapted MMI effects based on self-imaging have been reported [7, 8]. MMI effects are very useful for many optical applications such as ring laser and Mach–Zehnder structure. Recently, plasmonic devices that used MMI effects based on self-imaging have been reported by several research groups [9, 10]. Y. Kou et al. have adapted MMI effects for a demultiplexer, a wavelength-selective splitter, and an active tunable splitter in the metal–insulator–metal (MIM) structure [9]. MMI effects can be used for plasmonic devices in nano-scale photonic integrated circuits.

In this paper, we exploit MMI effects to improve the coupling efficiency between a plasmonic bus waveguide and a plasmonic disk resonator. The proposed structure is constituted of the MIM structure with a gap structure. We theoretically calculate the optimal thickness of the dielectric layer, the width of the bus waveguide, and the gap between the bus waveguide and the resonator. Using the finite-difference time-domain (FDTD) method, we numerically evaluate the characteristic of the designed structure. The FDTD simulations are performed by MIT Electromagnetic Equation Propagation (MEEP) [11]. MEEP has been used by several groups for numerical research in plasmonics [12, 13].

Section1.Heading: Theoretical and numerical analysis of the plasmonic resonator with a gap structure
Section1.Para:
Figure 1 shows the plasmonic resonator with a gap structure, for (a) from x–y plane and (b) from x–z plane. The refractive index of the dielectric layer and that of the substrate are set to 1.45, which is close to that of silicon dioxide. Both metal layers are silver whose permittivity is given by the Drude model according to Eq. (1):
1
$$ \varepsilon(\omega) = {\varepsilon_{\infty}} - \frac{{\omega _{\mathrm{p}}}^{2}}{(\omega^{2}+i\gamma\omega)}, $$ where ε ∞ is the relative permittivity at infinite frequency, ω p is the plasma frequency, and γ is the collision frequency; these parameters are set to 1.0, 1.37×1016 s−1, and 3.23×1013 s−1, respectively [14]. The width of the bus waveguide is denoted by w in Fig. 1(a). The gap between the bus waveguide and the resonator is denoted by s in Fig. 1(a). The thickness of the dielectric layer is denoted by t in Fig. 1(b).
Fig. 1
Schematics of the nano-plasmonic resonator with a gap structure for (a) disk resonator. (b) Cross-sectional view of the bus waveguide and the disk resonator with a gap structure

Section2.Heading: Thickness of the dielectric layer
Section2.Para:
The effective refractive index of the gap structure is calculated when the light with the wavelength of 1550 nm impinges on the structure shown in Fig. 1. Figure 2 shows the effective refractive index of the gap structure that has thicknesses of the dielectric layer (t) from 10 to 200 nm. The lines marked by circles and triangles correspond to the real part and the imaginary part of the effective refractive indices. The real part of the effective refractive index is increased when the thickness of the dielectric layer is decreased. The imaginary part of the effective refractive index is similarly increased when the thickness of the dielectric layer is decreased. The thickness of the dielectric layer is set to 50 nm.
Fig. 2
The real and imaginary parts of the effective refractive indices as functions of t

Section2.Heading: Width of the bus waveguide
Section2.Para:
To design the structure to guide single-mode gap plasmon polaritons (GPPs), we investigate the normalized frequency (V gsp) with respect to the width of the bus waveguide. V gsp is given by Eq. (2) [15]:
2
$$ V_{\mathrm{gsp}} \cong2w \sqrt{\frac{\pi\varepsilon_{\mathrm{d}}\sqrt{\vert \varepsilon_{\mathrm{d}}-\varepsilon(\omega)\vert }}{\lambda \vert \varepsilon(\omega)\vert \mathit{t}}} $$ where ε d is the refractive index of the dielectric layer and λ is the light wavelength. Figure 3 shows V gsp of the bus waveguide with a gap structure as a function of w. V gsp increases when w increases. The width of the bus waveguide needs to fulfill Eq. (3) for propagating single-mode GPPs [15]:
3
$$ 1.73 \leq V_{\mathrm{gsp}} \leq\pi. $$ The width of the bus waveguide that fulfills Eq. (3) is between 300 and 550 nm. The width of the bus waveguide is set to 300 nm.
Fig. 3
Normalized frequencies of the fundamental and the first-order modes of the GPPs as functions of w

Section2.Heading: Beat length of MMI effects
Section2.Para:
The electric field distribution in the bus waveguide is coupled to the opposite sides of the bus waveguide after each beat length and forms a repetitive field distribution when the fundamental mode and the first-order mode interfere with each other. The beat length of MMI effects is calculated by the following equation [9]:
4
$$ L = \pi/ (\beta_{0} - \beta_{1}) $$ where β 0 and β 1 are propagation constants of the fundamental mode and first-order mode, respectively. Figure 4 shows effective refractive indices of the fundamental and the first-order modes of the GPPs as functions of w at wavelength of 1550 nm. The lines marked by open circles and closed circles correspond to effective refractive indices of the fundamental and the first-order modes. The cutoff width of the first-order mode is below 500 nm. The width of the bus waveguide for a multi-mode waveguide is set to 600 nm for propagating the fundamental and the first-order modes in the bus waveguide. Effective refractive indices of the fundamental and the first-order modes are 1.98 and 1.52 with w=600 nm, respectively. The beat length L calculated by Eq. (4) is 1650 nm when the width of the bus waveguide is 600 nm for a wavelength of 1550 nm.
Fig. 4
Effective refractive indices of the fundamental and the first-order modes of the GPPs as functions of w
We designed that the position of the resonator is set at the beat length after the width of the bus waveguide is widened from 300 nm to 600 nm.

To obtain the optimal value of s in the MMI coupling, we investigate the output by simulating the schematics shown in Fig. 5(a). In order to compare the MMI coupling with the conventional side coupling, we investigate the output of the schematics shown in Fig. 5(b) as well. The radius of the curved waveguide is 500 nm [see Fig. 5(a) and (b)]. The width of the waveguide at input port is 300 nm and it is widened to 600 nm at the coupling portion [see Fig. 5(a)]. The width of the waveguide is 300 nm [see Fig. 5(b)]. The length of the waveguide from widened point to the coupling portion is 1650 nm which corresponds to the beat length at a wavelength of 1550 nm [see Fig. 5(a)]. The gap between the waveguide and the curved waveguide [denoted by s in Fig. 5(a) and (b)] is varied from 10 to 100 nm. A continuous wave of wavelength 1550 nm is incident at the input port [see Fig. 5(a) and (b)]. The output intensity is detected at the output port [see Fig. 5(a) and (b)].
Fig. 5
Schematic of the structure used to calculate the coupling between the waveguide and the resonator by using FDTD method for (a) the MMI coupling and (b) the conventional side coupling

Figure 6 shows the output intensities and the insertion loss obtained by the simulations as function of s. The lines marked by circles and triangles correspond to output intensities of the coupling using MMI effects and the conventional side coupling. The line marked by squares corresponds to the insertion loss of the curved waveguide. Output intensities of the coupling using MMI effects are 1.5 times greater than that of the conventional side coupling at every gap that ranges from 10 to 100 nm. The coupling using MMI effects is effective for coupling from the bus waveguide to the ring resonator. The output intensity increases with decreasing s and becomes maximum at s=10 nm. However, the insertion loss of the curved waveguide similarly increases with decreasing s. The insertion loss becomes maximum with s=10 nm. Devices are required to have a small insertion loss. Therefore, we deduce that the optimal s is 30 nm.
Fig. 6
The output intensities obtained by the simulations as function of s

We investigate electric field profiles at the coupling portion of the coupling using MMI effects and the conventional side coupling. Figure 7 shows the electric field profiles (|E|) at the coupling portion from x–z plane for (a) MMI coupling and for (b) the conventional side coupling. Due to MMI effects based on self-imaging, electric field profiles of MMI coupling are shifted towards the disk resonator [see Fig. 7(a)]. On the other hand, electric field profiles of the conventional side coupling stay at the center of the waveguide [see Fig. 7(b)]. Therefore, the coupling coefficient of the coupling using MMI effects is larger than that of the conventional side coupling. The coupling using MMI effects can be only used for the coupling from the input bus waveguide to the disk resonator because the coupling from the disk resonator to the output bus waveguide cannot exploit MMI effects based on self-imaging. Electric field profiles of the disk resonator cannot be varied by using MMI effects based on self-imaging because the shape of the disk resonator cannot be changed.
Fig. 7
Electric field profiles (|E|) at the coupling portion from x–z plane for (a) MMI coupling and for (b) the conventional side coupling

Section1.Heading: Characteristics of the nano-plasmonic disk resonator with a gap structure using MMI coupling
Section1.Para:
Figure 8(a) shows the schematic of the nano-plasmonic disk resonator. The radius of the disk resonator is set to 500 nm. The gap between the input bus waveguide and the resonator is 30 nm. The width of the input bus waveguide at the input port and the output bus waveguide is 300 nm. The width of the coupling portion between the input bus waveguide and the resonator is widened to 600 nm. The length of the waveguide from the widened portion to the coupling portion is 1650 nm.
Fig. 8
(a) Schematic of the nano-plasmonic disk resonator, (b) the output intensity as a function of the wavelength, and (c) electric field profiles (|E|) of the nano-plasmonic disk resonator at the center of the dielectric layer for an on-resonance wavelength of 1489 nm

The coupling between the input bus waveguide and the nano-plasmonic disk resonator is adapted with MMI coupling. Figure 8(b) shows the output intensity as a function of the wavelength. The resonance wavelength of the disk resonator is 1489 nm for which the output intensity is −20 dB. Figure 8(c) shows electric field profiles (|E|) of the nano-plasmonic disk resonator at the center of the dielectric layer for an on-resonance wavelength of 1489 nm. As shown in Fig. 8(c), the cavity mode of the GPPs is excited in the nano-plasmonic disk resonator at the on-resonance wavelength of 1489 nm. GPPs of the output bus waveguide are feeble because of poor coupling between the resonator and the output bus waveguide. However, on the other hand, GPPs are strongly coupled between the input bus waveguide and the nano-plasmonic disk resonator. Therefore, the MMI coupling is effective for the coupling between the bus waveguide and the nano-plasmonic disk resonator.

Section1.Heading: Conclusions
Section1.Para: We have presented a nano-plasmonic disk resonator using MMI coupling and designed the optimal structure to maximize the output intensity. For a wavelength of 1550 nm, the optimal thickness of the dielectric layer, width of the wavelength, and the gap between the bus waveguide and the resonator are 50, 300, and 30 nm, respectively. The length of the bus waveguide from widened point to the coupling portion is 1650 nm, which corresponds to the beat length at a wavelength of 1550 nm. The coupling intensity using MMI effects becomes 1.5 times greater than that of the conventional side coupling method. MMI coupling can be only used for the coupling from the input bus waveguide to the disk resonator because MMI coupling based on self-imaging is not effective for the coupling from the disk resonator to the output bus waveguide. Therefore, we should investigate the optimal coupling from the disk resonator to the output bus waveguide.
The nano-plasmonic disk resonator using MMI coupling has the potential to be a plasmonic resonant component in photonic integrated circuits.

Acknowledgments.Heading: Acknowledgements
Acknowledgments.SimplePara: This work was carried out using the equipment provided by the Cybermedia Center of the Osaka University.
